Python tricks that make your life easierÂ¶

In [1]: import pytraj as pt

In [2]: traj = pt.load_sampe_data('tz2')[:3]
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
AttributeError                            Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-2-f444f195aa95> in <module>()
----> 1 traj = pt.load_sampe_data('tz2')[:3]

AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute 'load_sampe_data'

In [3]: traj
␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀Out[3]: 
<pytraj.Trajectory, 101 frames, include:
<Topology: 223 atoms, 13 residues, 1 mols, non-PBC>>

UnpackingÂ¶

In [4]: a, b, c = traj[0], traj[1], traj[2]

In [5]: a, b, c
Out[5]: (<Frame with 223 atoms>, <Frame with 223 atoms>, <Frame with 223 atoms>)

ZippingÂ¶

In [7]: h_indices = pt.select_atoms(traj.top, '@H')

In [8]: n_indices = h_indices - 1

In [9]: list(zip(h_indices, n_indices))[:-5]
Out[9]: [(14, 13), (38, 37), (52, 51), (76, 75), (91, 90), (105, 104), (112, 111)]

Sliding windowsÂ¶

In [10]: for value in pt.tools.n_grams([0, 2, 4, 5, 7, 9], 2):
   ....:     print(value)
   ....: 
(0, 2)
(2, 4)
(4, 5)
(5, 7)
(7, 9)

Flattening listsÂ¶

In [11]: a = [[0, 54, 6], [[6, 7, 8], [9, 7, 5]]]

In [12]: print(pt.tools.flatten(a))
[0, 54, 6, 6, 7, 8, 9, 7, 5]

Dictionary comprehensionsÂ¶

In [13]: a = ['one', 'two', 'three']

In [14]: b = [1, 2, 3]

In [15]: print(dict(zip(a, b)))
{'one': 1, 'three': 3, 'two': 2}

Get value from Dictionary if key does not existÂ¶

In [16]: a = dict(x=3, y=4)

In [17]: a
Out[17]: {'x': 3, 'y': 4}

In [18]: a.get('x')
␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀Out[18]: 3

In [19]: a.get('z', 100)
␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀Out[19]: 100

SetÂ¶

In [20]: set(res.name for res in traj.top.residues)
Out[20]: {'ASN', 'GLU', 'GLY', 'LYS', 'NME', 'SER', 'THR', 'TRP'}

Filter dataÂ¶

In [21]: a = [3, 8, 2, 9]

In [22]: list(filter(lambda x: x < 5, a))
Out[22]: [3, 2]

CombinationsÂ¶

In [23]: from itertools import combinations

In [24]: a = [3, 8, 2, 9]

In [25]: list(combinations(a, 3))
Out[25]: [(3, 8, 2), (3, 8, 9), (3, 2, 9), (8, 2, 9)]

Chain several iteratorsÂ¶

In [26]: from itertools import chain

In [27]: fi_0 = traj(0, 3)

In [28]: fi_0
Out[28]: 
<FrameIter with start=0, stop=3, step=1, n_frames=3, 
frame_indices=None, 
mask=None, autoimage=False, rmsfit=None, copy=False> 

In [29]: fi_1 = traj(5, 8)

In [30]: fi_1
Out[30]: 
<FrameIter with start=5, stop=8, step=1, n_frames=3, 
frame_indices=None, 
mask=None, autoimage=False, rmsfit=None, copy=False> 

In [31]: for frame in chain(fi_0, fi_1): print(frame)
␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀<Frame with 223 atoms>
<Frame with 223 atoms>
<Frame with 223 atoms>
<Frame with 223 atoms>
<Frame with 223 atoms>
<Frame with 223 atoms>
